content: hey @WG-async-foundations, time for our meeting
hey!
I somehow had something scheduled over this -- maybe I don't have the invite on my calendar?
However, I wanted to talk a bit about async vision doc stuff :)
Sounds good. Before that, announcements – I know of one big thing
i'll try to monitor in any case
and dump some notes later

Sounds good. Before that, announcements – I know of one big thing

and that is the must_not_suspend lint RFC completing FCP
Is there anything else?
Not from me; I haven't had much time for async work this week
If not I think there's nothing else to discuss.. now would be a good time to talk about async vision @nikomatsakis, but not sure whether/how you want to do that now :)
As a reminder, this PR (rendered) is the current state of Niko's drafting of the vision
The intent is to land something and start iterating from there
Only thing I have is this is on the way to being deployed! https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/82165
Wondering if people have any high-level thoughts, concerns around the vision draft
I'm probably going to spend the time taking a bit of a closer look in any case :)
I will as well :)

Regarding the personas in the async vision doc, I have a few in mind that I'm trying to flesh out (in all cases it is "person developing a"):

  • High-performance distributed networked services
  • Core dependency crate
  • Runtime
  • CLI tool
  • Client-side application
  • Long-lived daemon
  • Existing library/application using established libraries

tmandry said:

If not I think there's nothing else to discuss.. now would be a good time to talk about async vision nikomatsakis, but not sure whether/how you want to do that now :)

sadly i'm in this call-- but I wanted to say that
(a) I'd love to hear more about characters or anything else
(b) I want to iterate on the tenets and plan to put time into that next week, hopefully have a fresh draft on monday

(c) I'd lke to shoot for getting a first draft by end of march, so if you have thoughts on things you would like to contribute or care about, i'd love to hear those thought--maybe will work on a blog post about process there
fin
Putting some time on my calendar to read through it this weekend
the yield-safe lint RFC would make a nice addition to some of the stories actually
oh, and I want to merge the PR by EOD
I think I maybe had an edit or two left to do, I forget
but the hope was to move to follow-up PRs to refine the content
yeah I think @Bhargav Voleti said they would make one
oh, you mean the vision
it feels more like part of a story
Probably something I'd be interested in doing would be to draft a coherent story around concurrency APIs. Not sure what that would best fall under, but we can figure that out offline
Oh new meeting time! I completely forgot. Give me a minute to catch up!
@Esteban Küber I'm not sure if those are all distinct characters or just stories with some of the characters we have
one thing I did want to add: Webassembly
maybe a wasm-developer
Fair
:face_palm: forgot about WASM
(but again maybe that's just stories with existing folks)
Hmm. Regardless of breakdown between characters/stories I'm seeing a whole lot of use cases we need to consider :)
I'm trying to think of a way to simply / make it more manageable
It might be worth highlighting which aspects of each use case make it unique
my assumption is that we'll find they're not that unique
for e.g. a CLI it might not be very different than a client-side application, save for one or two things
That's what I'm trying to flesh out
and yes, the interesting part there is what the IO requirements might be and that they care about cross-platform
stdin/stdout for a CLI tool is interesting in a way that isn't for a GUI app
as well as the distinction between a daemon and a server or a cli tool are small
but having it as its own thing gives us a vocabulary for them :)
yes, fair
so then what we might end up with is a set of requirements, which various use cases have a subset of
The good thing is that we can focus on the joint set of cases that affect multiple use cases, while the disjoint set can... continue as it is
The analogy I keep going back to is: "if you need mmap, you're using mmap, not File and you clearly already don't care about portability"
yeah exactly

I was going to say that writing out a "two-way mapping" might even be useful, if we get into a really tricky design issue we might have to exploit the fact that e.g. you never care about requirements X and Y at the same time
Same for a low-level fuchsia specific daemon, or a high-throughput linux only dns proxy
How long do we have this meeting for? If it is until half-past, then we have a minute and a half :)

The analogy I keep going back to is: "if you need mmap, you're using mmap, not File and you clearly already don't care about portability"

Although even this isn't necessarily rock solid.. many OSes have a concept of memory mapped file, so maybe you just want something which abstracts over that concept..
Yes, it's only 30 minutes
It's usually the triage meeting, though we didn't have anything to triage today :)
I will say, and I think this is important, the use of emoji in the new vision draft is great :p
Okay, we are officially out of time
Thanks all for coming, and see you next week! :wave:
